title: The Goose That Laid the Golden Eggs
author: Aesop

content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a poor farmer and his wife. They had a small cottage with a thatched roof, a garden where they grew vegetables,
and a single goose that wandered freely in their yard. Though they worked hard from sunrise to sunset, they often found it difficult to make ends meet, for their crops were meager, and their savings
were few. One morning, as the farmer was collecting eggs from the henhouse, he noticed something strange. Among the ordinary eggs laid by his hens, there was one that gleamed with a soft, golden
light. He picked it up, and to his amazement, it was heavy—far heavier than any egg he had ever held before. When he cracked it open, he found that the yolk and the white were made of
pure, shimmering gold! The farmer could hardly believe his eyes. He rushed into the house, calling for his wife. "Look! Look what our goose has done!" he cried, holding up the golden egg.
His wife gasped in astonishment. They stared at each other, their hearts pounding with excitement. Could it be true? Had their humble goose really laid a golden egg?
The next morning, the farmer hurried to the henhouse again, and there it was—another golden egg, just as radiant as the first. Day after day, the goose laid a golden egg, and soon, the farmer and
his wife began to grow wealthy. They bought fine clothes, built a grand new house, and filled their pantry with the finest foods.
Their neighbors whispered in awe, wondering how such a poor couple had become so rich. But as time passed, the farmer and his wife grew greedy. "Why should we wait for one egg each day?"
the farmer grumbled. "If we could get all the gold at once, we would be richer than the king himself!" His wife agreed, her eyes gleaming with avarice. "Yes!
We must find out how the goose makes these eggs. Perhaps there is a great treasure inside her!" That night, as the goose slept peacefully in her nest, the farmer crept into the henhouse with a
sharp knife. His hands trembled, but his heart was set. "If I cut her open," he whispered to himself, "I will find all the gold at once!"
Without another thought, he plunged the knife into the goose’s side. But when he looked inside, there was no gold—only blood and feathers.
The goose let out a terrible cry and collapsed, lifeless, in his arms. The farmer’s heart sank as he realized what he had done. Not only had he lost the goose, but he had also lost the golden
eggs forever. Tears streamed down his face as he carried the poor goose back to the house. His wife, seeing what had happened, wept bitterly. "We were fools!" she sobbed.
"We had everything we needed, and now we have nothing!" The farmer buried the goose beneath the old apple tree in their garden, where the golden eggs had once brought them such joy.
From that day on, the farmer and his wife lived in sorrow. They had learned a hard lesson: greed had cost them their fortune, their happiness, and the life of their beloved goose.
And though they worked harder than ever, they never again knew the comfort and security they had once taken for granted. And so, the tale of the goose that laid the golden eggs serves as a
reminder to all who hear it: be grateful for what you have, for greed can turn even the greatest blessings into the deepest regrets.
